hints_html: How are inflection points related to the second derivative?
hints_latex: How are \textbf{inflection points} related to the second derivative?
hints_raw: How are '''inflection points''' related to the second derivative?
question: A 01
sols_html:
\(\displaystyle f\) has an inflection point wherever \(\displaystyle f''\) changes sign. Thus we begin by looking for the zeroes of \(\displaystyle f''\):

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) &= \sin(x) + ax^2 \\ f'(x) &= \cos(x) + 2ax \\ f''(x) &= -\sin(x) + 2a\end{aligned}\]

Solving for a, we find that \(a = \tfrac12 \sin(x)\). Since \(-1 \leq \sin(x) \leq 1\), we have \(-\tfrac{1}{2} \leq a \leq \tfrac{1}{2}\).

But by the same inequalities, \(0 \leq f''(x) \leq 2\) when \(a = \tfrac12\). Similarly, \(-2 \leq f''(x) \leq 0\) when \(a = -\tfrac12\). In these cases, \(\displaystyle f\) has no inflection points since \(\displaystyle f''\) does not change sign.

Therefore \(-\tfrac{1}{2} < a < \tfrac{1}{2}\). This is equivalent to answer \({\color{blue}\text{(D)}}\).

statement_html:
Let \(\displaystyle f(x) = \sin(x) + ax^2\). Which of the following conditions describes all values of a for which f HAS inflection points?

(a) \(\displaystyle |a| > \tfrac12\)

(b) \(\displaystyle a > \tfrac12\)

(c) \(a \geq \tfrac12\)

(d) \(|a| < \tfrac12\)

(e) \(|a| \leq \tfrac12\)
